importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the news report indicates the current status of the flooding crisis in Mexico, highlighting the ongoing humanitarian and environmental impact.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding events occurred over a period of time last week, indicating a prolonged environmental crisis with cascading effects on infrastructure and communities.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.

The National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief, Laura Velazquez Alzua, reported 65 people still missing, with the highest numbers in Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Forty-three people are missing in Hidalgo, 18 in Veracruz, and four in Puebla.
Thousands of military troops from the Mexican Army, Air Force, and National Guard have been deployed to assist with rescue, food, and clean water distribution in inaccessible areas.
About 100,000 houses have been affected, with some near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, which led to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall was recorded in Cerro Azul, Veracruz (280mm) and Cuetzalan del Progreso, Puebla (286mm).
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of electricity supply in the affected states, where about 263,000 users lost power.
President Claudia Sheinbaum stated that there were no clear meteorological warnings predicting the extreme rainfall magnitude, raising questions about Mexico’s early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Severe flooding in five Mexican states—Veracruz, Hidalgo, Puebla, and Queretaro—has resulted in at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing, with the heaviest rainfall linked to the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond. The National Civil Protection Coordination and President Claudia Sheinbaum led a national response involving thousands of military personnel to deliver food, water, and emergency aid, while over 100,000 homes were affected. Despite efforts, infrastructure, especially electricity, was severely damaged, with about 263,000 users losing power. The event has raised serious questions about Mexico’s meteorological warning systems, as no clear signs of extreme rainfall were detected beforehand.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
